p: Of the sixteen articles written by physicians, fifteen advocated for a proactive ( Trope and Liberman, 2003) or leadership ( Ludmerer, 2014) role for medicine in fighting climate change. This group showed urgency for improving energy practices (75%), expressed concern about health conditions caused by increasing air pollution (81%), and commonly cited education as an antidote climate change (88%). These authors widely called for partnerships between health care and government agencies (81%). All considered changing health trends (100%), and over half considered ethical commitments (56%) as prerogatives for action.
